what you’re noticing there is what the “ethics in games journalism” crowd never could figure out, and that is something called a ‘separation of departments.’ 

see, to avoid conflicts of interests where the advertising team and their deals can influence the editorial staff’s writing, or where the writers can influence the advertising staff, the two departments are often kept entirely separate from each other, not communicating what the other is doing or mingling together. otherwise you would get a kane and lynch 2 scenario where an editor will say something that makes the advertisers angry and get fired. 

so when kotaku, splitner, and the greater gizmodo network say “fuck amazon today” but their banner ads and kinja deals are promoting amazon, you’re actually seeing properly separated journalistic integrity in action.

you’re either being deliberately disingenuous, or you do not understand the difference between quoting (which, as thenoblerobot has pointed out a few times now, requires attribution) and lifting wholesale.

the passage in question appears in the work absent context or attribution; a player that has not read the work from which the passage in question was lifted could reasonably be assumed to believe that passage came from the creators of the game, and not from an external source like the novel from which it was lifted. this is the absolute definition of taking the work of another and representing it as one’s own through failure to acknowledge originating source.

the examples you’re giving—like superboy saying “we’re not in kansas anymore”—fall under what’s commonly thought of as “public domain,” but is more accurately defined as common public knowledge. public domain is a specific legal term applying to works whose copyright protection has expired (and is not under consideration for renewal); common public knowledge refers to parlance and turns of phrase that are so strongly ingrained in the cultural consciousness that people quote them out of hand without really thinking about it (thus “may the force be with you”).

a relatively obscure passage in a novel that has not been widely read does not meet that definition—and particularly not when it appears without any context or attribution in a work whose primary distribution audience is unlikely to have direct familiarity with the work in question.

also worth noting: your argument that english-speaking persons are hypocrites for believing in “intellectual property” is absolutely facile. apart from groups of persons who have never had contact with any group of people other than their own, there is no language on the planet that does not borrow words, phrases, and grammatical constructs from other languages. english is the easiest target largely because it is such a weird patchwork of latin, german, french, and a few others—but find me a single anime that doesn’t slot an english word into an otherwise unbroken japanese vo track, or a german advertisement that does not, at some point, make reference to a word or concept that originated in another language.

it can be argued that the formation and communication of linguistic ideas is a creative effort, but it is not a creative effort in the same sense that writing a story, creating a piece of visual art, or composing a song is.

dude, attempting to create an analogy between dreaming of being a sheep and potentially damaging representations of trans persons that have real-world analogues is not a good look.

i can imagine myself throwing fireballs at turtle-dragons all day long, but there are no real turtle-dragons for me to take my “fantasies” out on.

there are people—real people—who are trans in the world, and fiction has a nasty habit of informing the way people react to the world around them. see also: the war of the worlds (given the reaction to the initial radio play), 1984 (given everyone and their brother quoting it these days), fahrenheit 451, romeo and juliet (because far too many people interpret a tragedy as a romance), and so on ad libitum.

no, fiction does not cause negative actions in the real world, but it can and does help to mold thinking—in both the absence and presence of context. fiction consumed in the presence of real-world context tends to have an ameliorating effect on prejudice, whereas fiction consumed in the absence of context can often have the opposite effect.

one other thing: fiction does not exist in a vacuum. it is and always has been a reflection of the time period, social order, and general cultural mien that exists at the time of its creation. that reflection can often be distorted, sure, but it’s still a reflection—even when it’s imperfect.

if that imperfection has the capacity to have a negative impact on real people, it behooves the author to have a care about how they are presenting fictional characters that too often will be taken as representative of those real people.

next time you want to try a sophistry-laden argument concerning the nature of fiction on someone, try not doing it to a professor of literature; it’s not the best strategy.
